Dear Mrs. Fernandez:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
07/11/2019. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the ISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4111 Job description.
An institution shall provide a job description for each staff
position that identifies rules, required qualifications, and lines of
authority.
One out of thirty-seven applicable personnel records reviewed did not contain a job
description.
REPEAT CITATION FROM 04/20/2018 RENEWAL INSPECTION
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(b) A true copy of verification of education from an accredited
college or university where minimum education requirements
are specified by rule.
One out of thirty-seven applicable personnel records reviewed did not contain true
copy of verification of education. It is noted that a photocopy of the transcript was
present.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(c) Verification of high school diploma or GED when
specified by rule.
4

One out of thirty-seven applicable personnel records reviewed did not contain
verification of high school diploma.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(d) Work history.
One out of thirty-seven applicable personnel records reviewed did not contain
verification of work history. It is noted that the record was hired onsite during a job
fair.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to
employment from persons unrelated to the employee and which
are less than 12 months old.
Three out of thirty-seven applicable personnel records reviewed did not contain
three dated references. One record contained only two refences, whereas two
records contained no references. It is noted that the two records that contained no
references were hired onsite during a job fair.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department of human
services, the equivalent state or Canadian provincial agency, or
equivalent agency in the country where the person usually
resides, that the person has not been determined to be a
perpetrator of child abuse or child neglect. The documentation
5

shall be completed not more than 30 days prior to the start of
employment and every 12 months thereafter.
Three out of thirty-seven personnel records under one year of hire did not contain or
contained a late central registry check. One personnel record contained a central
registry clearance 12 days after the staff person was employed, whereas two did not
have verification of one being completed.
Three out of eight personnel records hired beyond one year did not contain an
annually updated central registry clearance.
REPEAT CITATION FROM 04/20/2018 RENEWAL INSPECTION
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(j) A written evaluation of the employee's performance within
30 days of the completion of the probationary period or within
180 days, whichever is less, and a written evaluation of the
employee’s performance annually thereafter.
One out of eight applicable personnel records reviewed did not contain an annual
performance evaluation.
REPEAT CITATION FROM 04/20/2018 RENEWAL INSPECTION
R 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and volunteers.
The licensee shall document, prior to employment, that each
employee and volunteer who has contact with residents 4 or
more hours per week for more than 2 consecutive weeks is free
from communicable tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable
tuberculosis shall be verified within the 1-year period before
employment and shall be verified every 1 year after the last
verification or prior to the expiration of the current verification.
6

Five out of eight personnel records hired beyond one yea did not contain an annually
updated TB test.
Three out of thirty-seven personnel records hired less than one year did not meet
the requirements of this rule. Two records did not contain a TB test, whereas the
third record contained a TB test completed twenty-one days after date of hire.
REPEAT CITATION FROM 04/20/2018 RENEWAL INSPECTION
R 400.4128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training.
(1) The licensee shall provide an orientation program for new
employees. Job shadowing shall not be the only form of
orientation. The orientation shall include the following:
(a) The institution's purpose, policies, and procedures,
including discipline, crisis intervention techniques, and
emergency and safety procedures.
One out of thirty-seven applicable personnel records reviewed did not contain
verification of an orientation occurring.
R 400.4144 Admission health screening; physical examinations.
(2) An institution shall have the following documentation of an
admission physical examination for each resident, unless an
earlier examination is medically indicated:
(b) For a resident 3 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 1 year prior to
admission or a new physical examination shall be completed
within 30 calendar days after admission.
One out of six case records reviewed contained a physical examination completed
thirty-four days after admission.
R 400.4146 Immunizations.
(1) A resident shall have current immunizations as required by
the department of community health.
7

One out of six case records reviewed contained an overdue immunization. It is
noted that the Meningococcal B Cat B was overdue as of 08/09/2017, whereas the
residents MICR was completed by the facility on 11/09/2018.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
There were no ISEP violations noted.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract/Policy violation. Please
note that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
RFCJJ Contract Contractor Responsibilities-Services to be Provided-
Oct 17: 2.10.b Standardized Assessment Tools
Page 8-9
The Contractor shall utilize the following assessment tools to
assess the youth’s overall progress in functioning while in the
residential program:
2) Michigan Juvenile Justice Assessment System (MJJAS).
The Contractor shall administer the required assessment tools
until the youth is released and document the scores in
MiSACWIS.
One out of six applicable case records reviewed did not contain the quarterly
MJJAS. It is noted that the facility was unable to access the case record in
MiSACWIS, and the attached MJJAS for completion. It is further noted that the
facility completed its required treatment planning outside of MiSACWIS and has
the DHHS worker upload the reports and other case related information.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R 400.4147 Dental care.
(3) Reexamination shall be provided at least every 14 months
unless greater frequency is indicated.
One applicable case record reviewed indicates the resident being evaluated by the
dentist on 03/21/2019 and documented on a progress note by the dental assistant.
8

It is recommended that annual dental examinations be completed by the dentist
using the Dental Screening form.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The facility submitted a corrective action plan for the 04/20/2018 renewal inspection
report. It successfully addressed the following as no repeat citations were noted:
First aid/CPR certification cards, resident photo updates, supervisor signature on
ISP/USP’s, school administration notification verification, DHHS clothing inventory
form, uploaded medicals and dentals into MiSACWIS, and timely signatures on
treatment plans. Repeat citations include: Job descriptions, annual central registry
checks, performance evaluations and annual TB test verification within personnel
files.
The facility submitted four corrective actions plans from the time of the last renewal
inspection dated 04/20/2018 through its placement on a six-month provisional license
dated 02/24/2019.
SIR# 2018C0219053 initiated on 05/23/2018 cited the facility for restraining a resident
when not warranted. The corrective action plan included all staff training in verbal
and physical intervention training, as well as staff suspension, and individual
supervision with staff regarding the incident.
SIR# 2018C0219063 initiated on 08/03/2018 cited the facility for resident restraint and
seclusion when not warranted. The corrective action plan included training on when
restraint and seclusion is to be used, as well as staff termination.
SIR# 2018C0219067 initiated on 08/08/2018 cited the facility for staff supervision as a
resident had access to a cell phone and posted pictures of himself inside his bedroom
via social media. The corrective action plan included security training regarding
visitation and searching procedures, youth worker training on supervision, as well as
staff being searched prior to each shift.
SIR# 2019C0219005 initiated on 11/26/2018 cited the facility for staff abilities in
allowing two residents to enter a bedroom together unsupervised and fight. The
corrective action plan included staff termination, as well as revamping interview
9

questions, manager training on interviewing potential staff, as well as training on the
child protection law.
The facility submitted two corrective actions plans since being placed on a six-month
provision license dated 02/24/2019.
SIR# 2018C0219069 initiated on 09/12/2018 cited the facility for staff abilities and
failing to follow policy in conducting 15-minute bed checks in which a resident
committed suicide. The corrective action plan included staff terminations, as well as
retraining of staff in staff-to-resident ratio related to sleeping hours, supervisor
random video reviews, replacement of air vents, having an insurance physical
analysis completed, establishing monthly suicide risk building assessments, and
establishing layered process audits. The facility is in compliance with the corrective
action plan as evidenced through administrative, staff, and resident interviews.
SIR# 2019C0219017 initiated on 01/29/2019 cited the facility for staff abilities as a
result of staff swatting a flip flop at a resident. The corrective action plan included the
termination of staff, and all staff being retrained on resident rights, as well as hiring
managers being trained in interviewing.
VI. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
